Version: 29.4

Utilizarea regulilor de potrivire

Jest uses "matchers" to let you test values in different ways. This document will introduce some commonly used matchers. For the full list, see the expect API doc.

Validatori comuniâ€‹

Cel mai simplu mod de a testa o valoare este cu egalitatea exactÄƒ.

test('two plus two is four', () => {
  expect(2 + 2).toBe(4);
});

Ãn acest cod, expect(2 + 2) returneazÄƒ un obiect "expectation". De obicei nu veÅ£i face mult cu aceste obiecte cu excepÅ£ia cÄƒ veÈ›i apela validatori pe ele. Ãn acest cod, .toBe(4) este validator. CÃ¢nd Jest se executÄƒ, el urmÄƒreÈ™te toÈ›i validatorii eÈ™uaÈ›i astfel Ã®ncÃ¢t sÄƒ poatÄƒ afiÈ™a frumos mesajele de eroare.

toBe uses Object.is to test exact equality. If you want to check the value of an object, use toEqual:

test('object assignment', () => {
  const data = {one: 1};
  data['two'] = 2;
  expect(data).toEqual({one: 1, two: 2});
});

toEqual verificÄƒ recursiv fiecare cÃ¢mp dintr-un obiect sau un array.

tip

toEqual ignores object keys with undefined properties, undefined array items, array sparseness, or object type mismatch. To take these into account use toStrictEqual instead.

You can also test for the opposite of a matcher using not:

test('adding positive numbers is not zero', () => {
  for (let a = 1; a < 10; a++) {
    for (let b = 1; b < 10; b++) {
      expect(a + b).not.toBe(0);
    }
  }
});

AdevÄƒrâ€‹

In tests, you sometimes need to distinguish between undefined, null, and false, but you sometimes do not want to treat these differently. Jest conÅ£ine utillitare care vÄƒ permit sÄƒ fiÈ›i expliciÈ›i despre ceea ce doriÈ›i.

  • toBeNull valideazÄƒ doar null
  • toBeUndefined valideazÄƒ doar undefined
  • toBeDefined este opusul lui toBeUndefined
  • toBeTruthy valideazÄƒ orice declaraÈ›ie dacÄƒ este adevÄƒratÄƒ
  • toBeFalsy valideazÄƒ orice declaraÈ›ie dacÄƒ este falsÄƒ

De exemplu:

test('null', () => {
  const n = null;
  expect(n).toBeNull();
  expect(n).toBeDefined();
  expect(n).not.toBeUndefined();
  expect(n).not.toBeTruthy();
  expect(n).toBeFalsy();
});

test('zero', () => {
  const z = 0;
  expect(z).not.toBeNull();
  expect(z).toBeDefined();
  expect(z).not.toBeUndefined();
  expect(z).not.toBeTruthy();
  expect(z).toBeFalsy();
});

Ar trebui sÄƒ utilizaÅ£i validatorul care corespunde cel mai exact cu ceea ce doreÈ™ti sÄƒ facÄƒ codul tÄƒu.

Numereâ€‹

Majoritatea modurilor de comparare a numerelor au validatori echivalenÅ£i.

test('two plus two', () => {
  const value = 2 + 2;
  expect(value).toBeGreaterThan(3);
  expect(value).toBeGreaterThanOrEqual(3.5);
  expect(value).toBeLessThan(5);
  expect(value).toBeLessThanOrEqual(4.5);

  // toBe and toEqual are equivalent for numbers
  expect(value).toBe(4);
  expect(value).toEqual(4);
});

Pentru egalitatea numerelor cu virgulÄƒ mobilÄƒ, utilizaÅ£i toBeCloseTo Ã®n loc de toEqual, deoarece nu vrei ca un test sÄƒ depindÄƒ de o eroare micÄƒ de rotunjire.

test('adding floating point numbers', () => {
  const value = 0.1 + 0.2;
  //expect(value).toBe(0.3);           This won't work because of rounding error
  expect(value).toBeCloseTo(0.3); // This works.
});

Åiruri de caractereâ€‹

PuteÅ£i verifica È™iruri de caractere cu expresii regulate utilizÃ¢nd toMatch:

test('there is no I in team', () => {
  expect('team').not.toMatch(/I/);
});

test('but there is a "stop" in Christoph', () => {
  expect('Christoph').toMatch(/stop/);
});

Arrays and iterablesâ€‹

You can check if an array or iterable contains a particular item using toContain:

const shoppingList = [
  'diapers',
  'kleenex',
  'trash bags',
  'paper towels',
  'milk',
];

test('the shopping list has milk on it', () => {
  expect(shoppingList).toContain('milk');
  expect(new Set(shoppingList)).toContain('milk');
});

ExcepÅ£iiâ€‹

If you want to test whether a particular function throws an error when it's called, use toThrow.

function compileAndroidCode() {
  throw new Error('you are using the wrong JDK!');
}

test('compiling android goes as expected', () => {
  expect(() => compileAndroidCode()).toThrow();
  expect(() => compileAndroidCode()).toThrow(Error);

  // You can also use a string that must be contained in the error message or a regexp
  expect(() => compileAndroidCode()).toThrow('you are using the wrong JDK');
  expect(() => compileAndroidCode()).toThrow(/JDK/);

  // Or you can match an exact error message using a regexp like below
  expect(() => compileAndroidCode()).toThrow(/^you are using the wrong JDK$/); // Test fails
  expect(() => compileAndroidCode()).toThrow(/^you are using the wrong JDK!$/); // Test pass
});
tip

The function that throws an exception needs to be invoked within a wrapping function otherwise the toThrow assertion will fail.

Åi mai multâ€‹

This is just a taste. Pentru o listÄƒ completÄƒ a validatorilor, verificaÈ›i documentaÈ›ia de referinÅ£Äƒ.

OdatÄƒ ce aÅ£i Ã®nvÄƒÅ£at despre validatorii disponibili, un bun pas urmÄƒtor este sÄƒ vedeÈ›i cum vÄƒ permite Jest sÄƒ testaÅ£i codul asincron.
